title: Clockface for laser engraver or cnc plasma

description.text:
imported photo of clock face from tower in London. Used Photoshop to remove background and filter feature to make into vector file. saved as bitmap. imported into inkscape
traced path
used object to path command saved as dxf. opened file in torchmate CAD to make sure the fill and objects were right.
toolpaths were not created.  the numbers will need to be welded to the frame, or you can ungroup the object, delete the numbers and use your own font.

description.text:
This is a coaster that features a color-changing inlay. When a hot beverage is set down on the coaster, a biohazard symbol emerges. The color changing filament is M3D's Chameleon 3D Ink. Because it is subjected to heat, I made the coaster base from ABS.

Pretty straightforward assembly, just print the two parts in the desired color(s) and glue together. I also sealed the coaster with XTC-3D epoxy.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Makerfarm 12

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Printed at .2mm height with a .4mm nozzle

Infill:

25%, 1mm thick top and bottom layers

Notes:

Print as you see fit. Again, I would recommend going with ABS for the body because it will be subjected to hot beverages.
After printing, I lightly sanded the body and logo. I glued the two pieces together and then sealed the entire coaster with XTC-3D epoxy.

title: Cobblebot Little Monster X-gantry with BLTouch

description.text:
Replacement X-Gantry for the Cobblebot Little Monster.

I've struggled to get this stupid printer working well. Bed leveling is an issue and I bought the BL-touch to address it, I'm testing this gantry out now, I plan to have it printed with Carbon-fiber PETG but for now am testing it with Standard PETG from Esun,

I've included a few spaces for the Bl-touch as well. print as needed

I've added holes to attach the BL-Tough https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bltouch-auto-bed-leveling-sensor-for-3d-printers/x/5685841#/
bed level sensor

I've included a STEP file if you need to edit this.

title: Dowel, nuts and bolts for Minifig TP Holder

description.text:
This is all the nuts, bolts and dowels (Sleeves) required for the Minifig TP Holder found here:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1277045

Edit: 12 June 2017

Experience has taught me the following:

  1. Use the 140 mm long sleeve I have just uploaded. 145 mm is slightly too long. Print this at 1.01 times the size of the .STL here
  2. Use the 45 mm long bolts and size/print them at 0.99 times the size of the .STL files here
  3. If at all possible, use PETG or ABS for the 45 mm bolts as thy need more strength than PLA prints

I leave all the other files here in case anyone wants to use them instead.

Enjoy.

All created as customised versions of Nut Job

Parakeet uses a SIMM800L rather than a cell phone to Upload Data to Nightscout.

About:

This case was influenced by Lehaiver's xDrip Wireless Bridge case v1.7 for the Nightscout/xDrip project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1481048

Assembly:

I have a pretty basic printer that does not do well with overhangs so, boards could only be located. I used Epoxy to secure the battery and boards in place and CA ( instant glue ) for the cover. Switch height is critical. The Switch should NOT open or close when the case is laid face down on a flat surface. The thru hole is meant to be drilled to final size.

Refer to project page for electronics assembly instructions.

Once you have the electronics assembly wired, double check your connections and place it in a cast iron frying pan away from anything flammable. Be careful not to short anything out. Insulate if necessary. Fully charge the Lithium battery. Power up, Check operation. Your battery should not get hot.

Mount electronics in Case and secure with epoxy.

I secured the back cover with masking tape and tested for a couple of days to confirm operation before gluing it permanently in place.

Project Documentation:

Parakeet Project Page
https://jamorham.github.io/#parakeet

What is the Parakeet ?
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B6mvYVNVC-fOQU5XQS14NERwYjA/view?pref=2&pli=1

Parakeet Project Documentation
https://github.com/jamorham/wixel-xDrip

Video set-up instructions
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sq1Vs4Vor7c
The You Tube video made by Andrew Abramowicz is well put together - complete and VERY helpful. However, I couldn't get my Wixel FW to compile using "make_all.bat". So, I ended up using the "MAKE" command from S. Black's xDrip documentation https://github.com/StephenBlackWasAlreadyTaken/wixel-xDrip (How do I use it ? Step 3:). This may just be a Windows 10.xx issue.

Parts List:

Switch, Latching 17x12x9mm

https://www.adafruit.com/product/1905

http://www.ebay.com/itm/2-x-Cell-Phone-Battery-for-Nokia-BL-5C-1650-1680-1681-1101-1110i-1200-1208-6205-/281848334118?hash=item419f784726

Wixel
https://www.pololu.com/product/1337

I build up a .15mm even layer of "Elmer's Disappearing Purple Glue Stick" over bare BS Glass and a .2mm initial layer to control warping. I can usually run quite a few parts through before having to reapply. Allow parts to cool to room temperature and they should self-release.

description.text: This is a Spool holder which I designed to go inside my SparkCube XL but I can fit other printers which are made from Slot6/Nut6 alluminium profiles and have the clearance for the spool.

Printer:

Sparkcube

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print the frame and the spool stopper once. You'll need two of the spool adpaters and two of the center cylinder pieces.

BoM:

  • 2x 608 Bearings
  • 2x M4 Nuts
  • 9x 6mmx6mm cylindrical magnets
  • 2x Slot nuts
  • 1x 8mmx105mm steel rod
  • Some M4 screws about 10mm

When printing ,some of the parts have to be rotated 180 degree to place them flat on your print bed.

put the magnets into the holes of the center cylinder, be careful to insert them in the right way so that the two pieces atrackt each other. Put one magnet into the end stopper.

slide the 8mm steel rod into the main frame, fix in place with nuts and screws. Mount the frame to your printer.

description.text:
Four tricky Cube Puzzles - can you get the pieces back into their boxes?

This year at Maker Faire Bay Area, Ultimaker is offering a challenge: Solve one of our 3D-printed Cube Puzzles and you get to keep it! Or 3D print one yourself with these files, in four different levels.

=====

Twitter: twitter.com/mathgrrl
Hacktastic blog: www.mathgrrl.com/hacktastic
Shapeways geekhaus store: www.shapeways.com/shops/mathgrrl

This design and all associated pictures and files are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial Share Alike license. If you want to use designs, images, or files outside of the terms of this license, please email [email protected].

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15mm

Notes:

All of the pieces print without supports, rafts, or brims.

Level 1 = Easy
The Soma Cube has 240 different solutions, so it’s easier to solve than the other puzzles. This puzzle was very popular in the 1960’s, and people enjoy assembling the pieces into many other pleasing shapes like stairs or pyramids.

Level 2 = Medium
The Hoffmann Cube is the earliest known 3x3x3 Cube Puzzle, created in 1893. This puzzle has only six types of solutions, up to symmetry. One interesting thing about the Hoffmann Cube is that all of its pieces are flat!

Level 3 = Hard
The Coffin Cube has only one solution and it is also known as the Half Hour Puzzle, created by Stewart Coffin. All four of the puzzle patterns used in our Cube Puzzle Challenge are from Stewart Coffin’s excellent book Geometric Puzzle Design.

Level 4 = Diabolical
The Nob Cube also has only one solution and it is notoriously difficult to solve. Some puzzle makers craft this puzzle out of wood and it is said that the puzzle is so difficult that solvers sometimes resort to examining the grain of the wood to figure out how the pieces fit together. Are you up to the challenge?

Design Your Own Puzzle Cube!

Have students use their favorite 3D design software to create their own Cube Puzzles. This project can be adapted for many different educational subject areas and at a variety of levels:

Beginner: Use Tinkercad or Morphi to place boxes together to construct puzzle pieces that fit together into a 3x3x3 cube. How do you know they will all fit together into the cube? Print out your puzzle and have fellow students try it out to rate its difficulty.

Intermediate: Use Blender, Fusion 360, or AutoCAD to create puzzle pieces, and use fillets and offsets so that the pieces are pleasant to hold and fit together nicely. Create a container box that will hold the assembled Cube Puzzle. Who can make the most difficult puzzle?

Fundraising: Print out students’ Cube Puzzles and create a solving event where parents and faculty try to solve the puzzles. Raise money for your school or classroom by charging per solving minute, having solving championships, or selling the Cube Puzzles themselves. You can inscribe one of the puzzle pieces in each Cube with text to personalize it for your school or event.

Designing with Code: Use OpenSCAD or BlocksCAD to create pieces for a Cube Puzzle by translating and arranging cubes. Add code that creates clearance for where pieces will touch each other. Make this clearance customizable so that it can be easily changed for printing on different 3D printers or with different settings.

Exploring Mathematics: Which other 3D shapes could be used in this type of puzzle? What types of polyhedra can fill space, and which of those can be used to create a puzzle whose pieces can slide together? As a starting point, think about 2D space-filling shapes and puzzles by exploring tessellations and tangrams.

Advanced: Use the software BurrTools to construct a Cube Puzzle, analyze it for constructability, and test how many solutions it has. Can you find a new 3x3x3 Cube puzzles that has only one solution? You can also try your hand at more advanced puzzles like interlocking Burr Puzzles or puzzles with unit shapes other than cubes.

Don't have a 3D printer, or want something fancy printed for you? We don't have the Cube Puzzle Quartet in our print-to-order store yet, but we have other cool stuff you can check out:

HIgh

100%

This is a scan of a small cat statue in a stretch pose. The statue was constantly being knocked off the window sill by our real cat who apparently didn't like the competition. The statue had some damage, so I repaired what I could and then scanned it with the DAVID SLS-2 scanner and TT-1 turntable. Then hid the remaining damage using meshmixer software. The result is an amazing replica of the original statue and it's very difficult to find where it was damaged. And now, printed out of ABS it's a lot tougher for our cat, Ziggy, to break. And even if he does manage to break it, I can just print another one! He is not pleased.

This prints really well. Just need some supports for under her left leg, and belly. Maybe the chin and the last third of her tail, depending on how well your printer handles overhangs.

It may help to drop the mesh in Z slightly into your bed during slicing. Perhaps 0.2 to 0.4mm at most. But I tried to set up the mesh so that it sits flat on your bed as is.

comments.text: I print on a glass bed too. The trick to use with any scanned solid like this one is to drop the model in Z about .4 to 1mm into the bed before slicing. The slicer will ignore any part of the model below the bed surface essentially chopping off the paws a small amount. This makes a perfectly flat surface which will stick to the bed much better.

Designed in TinkerCAD based on commercially available washers (USA). Simply print in NinjaFlex with 100% infill and install.

Glacier Bay 3075-561 (Shower Head Washer) - https://tinkercad.com/things/6ystCzdoCyx

For those who aren't technically inclined:
Teflon tape is never used for garden hoses, as they use a compression fitting. Shower heads also use a compression fitting, but a couple wraps of PTFE tape serve to prevent seizing-up (to facilitate future removal)—not to prevent leaks! If your garden hose or shower head leak, you need to install new gaskets.

title: Filament Spool Holder Brackets for Wombot (and others)

description.text:
This is part of a larger project for an automatic filament feeder, but is useful in itself.
Combined with the Spool Adapter here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1568146 it makes an almost frictionless spool holder.
The spool holder that came with my Wombot Exilis can cause the extruder head to lift slightly as the tension builds up on the filament. At some point, the spool unreels a little and the tension releases, letting the extruder head drop again.
This contributes to Z-axis printing issues.
These brackets are stronger and better designed than the originals and have open, slotted tops that allow spools to be easily lifted out and dropped in again.
Replacing the original support brackets with two of these and a length of M8 (approx 5/16 inch) allthread rod as an axle allows the spool to turn more freely. The next part of the project is a pair of adaptors that fit different sized spools and have ballrace bearings in them.

title: X-carriage with sensor mount for E3D direct-drive hinged extruder

description.text:
This is a slightly modified X-carriage originally produced by ffleurey. I upgraded the hot-end on my Prusa i3 to an E3D V6 and wanted to continue using the auto levelling sensor I had previously added. This is the sensor it was designed for: https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B008LT3XY2/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The idea of doing it this way was to make it a little more accessible for the odd occasion when I may need to adjust it (happens once in a blue moon), so I could see the sensor light when the probe is in use, and finally to get the sensor in a safer position. The original design of my printer's x-carriage included an addon for this type of sensor but made it protrude out beyond the frame/screen housing at the top and with a big enough print this might get in the way. This tucks it under the rest of the assembly and keeps it out of harm's way.

remixed_from.title: The Honda logo for motor bikes

description.text:
This hitch cover is a remix. I've modified it to accept a 69 mm x 69 mm x 1.5mm logo plate (the one I've included is a remix as well).

Simply slide the logo plate in from the top, the three small tabs will hold it in. When you want to change it out, just push on the logo plate from the back side at the top, slide it up and out.

Logo plate should be 1.5mm thick to fit snugly in the tabs. Raised lettering and logos are up to you!

To design your own logo plate, start with a 69x69x1.5mm cube, then draw your logo on top of it.

title: Printing glass on Ultimaker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ah well... not really glass... not real diamonds, but it has a diamond look... sort of Swarovski-style... More or less by accident, but i am surprised how good you can control the irregularity so it gets regular again. This is only the very first test... more on:
www.facebook.com/europerminutedesign
www.rooiejoris.nl

Print with very very high extruder speed and with a big [0.8mm] nozzle.
in sf46 the most important settings are:
layer thickness: 1.1mm
w/h ratio: 2.1
feed rate: 45
flow rate: 1250 [ in reality 2x, i did put my stepper driver not on micro stepping, but less steps a round, so it moves twice as fast as 'normal']
the extruder wheel is really spinning like crazy...!
temp: 240 deg UPDATE:
  • material is PLA
  • higher temp for more liquid PLA [be careful if your nozzle holder is not PEEK]
  • flow/feedrate depends also on your firmware i think in sf<40 i did 'normal' 0.8mm prints with more or less flowrate = 1.5*feedrate, with my first experiments with sf>40 i got very high values, maybe because my firmware still thinks it is using sf<40 [i am not so good in software...]
  • microstepping off, only for extruder, that is the one who needs high speed [on the ultimaker due to gears]
  • 0.8 nozzle was original nozzle drilled with 0.8mm drill, but also an ordinary closed bold [?!] could work
  • z-adjustments by hand did the control between smooth and irregular, higher z, more irregularity.

comments.text: Does anyone know how to scale this down to a .35 diameter nozzle?  I get a nice print, but no diamond pattern.
comments.author: Moniker

comments.text:
The easiest way is to play with the layer height by hand during printing every layer. I can control the effect. More layer height -
&
gt; more random, less layer height -
&
gt; straight lines.

description.text:
No one had a control panel that I wanted or fit my design needs for my filament extruder, so I made one. This control panel will support up to 3 slim switches and 1 larger switch, for a total of 4. The switch holes are covered but you notch as many as you need. They are designed so that you don't have holes all over your control panel. Below is a list of products that fit this print.

Digital PID Temperature Controller
http://www.ebay.com/itm/111974584206?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

DC Motor Speed Control Switch

I created this because I wanted protection for the on button when traveling. I was going to make it the shape of the razor but then I decided to make a simple cylinder since it will only be used when I travel. I posted this to share the idea more so than to share the files because it's easy to reproduce. This could also function as a shaver stand.

Remix of ulflindestrom mount, adding an optional antenna mount, straight design (round was nice but not strong enough), optional hole for the board camera..

Version 3

It suits my setup, where I put the mount on spacers on top of the frame so I can put the receiver under and the antenna from the bottom into the mount tubes.

Version 4

New version so we don't need spacers, the receiver goes in the mobius mount, there are holes to let the cable go under. It allows the battery to be at the front and thus more centered CG

My nephew wanted to make a miniature ten pin bowling game and found a suitable piece of wooden skirting board and a ball bearing to use as the ball. We grabbed a bowling pin from the Google 3D Warehouse (http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=d6b915030d74878f4fa86d12e3299e2d) and converted it from SketchUp to STL online using babel3d.com before sending it to cloud.netfabb.com to clean up the model. We designed a ramp for the ball in OpenSCAD to make the game more challenging than just rolling the ball by hand. The red stripe on the pins was added by hand with a marker pen.

title: GRAMiPhone Fixed - iPhone 6 Gramophone Horn
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a very small remix of the GRAMiPhone - iPhone 6 Gramophone Horn. All I did was fix the orientation of the model in case people didn't know how to. All the credit goes to the original.

This passive amplifier horn will amplify your phone's speaker without power. The horn profile is based on a Western Electric exponential horn. The horn is 7.5" long and press fits into the base. I added 0.010 clearance for the phone but when it printed it was still a tight fit.
Update Jan 5, 2016: I've modified the base to be friendly to printing without supports. There is still a round tube inside that may give problems without support. This depends on your printer's ability to print overhang layers. I've also increased the clearance for the phone so it's not so tight. The new base file name is signified by REV 2. https://youtu.be/QZo0a7ev3IU?t=9m26s

Notes:

I printed this on my XYZPrinting DaVinci 1.0 with XYZ filament. Used supports only on the base part and not the horn. To remove the support from inside the tube on the base I used a hair pin to push it out and it came out clean.

author: buckholt

description.text:
I found these needle tip plastic bottles that are immune to acetone.  In the States they can be found at Joanne Fabric store and are made by the Darice company.  The package says "Needle Tip Applicator Bottles and are currently $2.99 for a package of 6.  I designed the stand to hold 8 of these bottles and they were printed on a Printrbot Plus ( the stand is 150mm long).  See the instruction tab for glue-making instructions.  
Update:  I have improved the design.  After using, I found that the bottle wells were too shallow and the bottles were easily knocked over.  I increased the bottle well walls and now it is stable.  In addition, I added a handle.

Print the stand.  Fill the bottles half-full of acetone and add cut-up pieces of the same color filament.  Let stand for 30 minutes, shake the bottles, and out comes ABS-colored glue.  The needle tips help pinpoint the application of the glue. Label the bottles.  I printed 4  feet and glued them to the bottom of the stand.

comments.text: Update---It's been well over two years and the bottles are still working great.

comments.text: In sketch up you use 2 different materials. Then select all of one material, hide, export stl, and same for the other material.
comments.author: laird

comments.text: Got it. So I guess the right method of generating the two STLs would vary depending on the modeling tool. I can see how to do it in OpenSCAD (put conditionals all over the code to only render the objects that are the desired color). But in a visual modeling tool, that seems trickier. We'll all find out, etc.?
comments.author: laird

comments.text: There is no modeling tools that I know of that will do it for you.  Basically, you just have to model something and then split the model yourself into two seperate models, one for each color, making sure the objects are positioned so that when they are merged they make the shape you want.

comments.text: Model both in the same program, connect them as they would be printed.. remark out the second color... generate stl.. unremark the second color and remark out the first .. generate the second stl. :( Havent got to try it yet, because they havent sent me my replicator, but hoping thats the way it works :)

The Drivemyphone concept has won two competition ideas, 'ideias em caixa 2010' and 'idea2product 2011 Portugal'. Keep in mind that it man not be so innovative now in 2106, but back in 2010 it had some potential.

The DriveMyPhone has also won venture capital funding, that did not go as planed. A patent for the model was also submitted, you can read it the attachment section below. All idea competition take in account not only the product but also the marketing and sales strategy, so that was also the reason it won, i will not enter in detail in this field becaus it is out of context here in instructables.

print_settings.Notes:: What I printed is about 6 inches across but in the file I think it is only 4. For a decent size that you can hang on your wall that isnt small set the X and Y scale to 1.4 and the Z to 0.8 (the Z dimension is only to save some filament). I printed this on high speed and printed it with a brim for it to retain its shape.

description.text: This is a simply a design for the crest of Pi Kappa Phi fraternity, the Star Shield. It is easy to print and looks great on a wall! For fun I engraved the class names on the back (its hard to see because I didnt cut out the brimmed portion). I customized it with for a few guys in my fraternity to include the Pi Kappa Phi letters, chapter designation, and initials.

Printer:

TAZ

Resolution:

Fast

Notes:

What I printed is about 6 inches across but in the file I think it is only 4. For a decent size that you can hang on your wall that isnt small set the X and Y scale to 1.4 and the Z to 0.8 (the Z dimension is only to save some filament). I printed this on high speed and printed it with a brim for it to retain its shape.

Solidworks, started from a circle, made a hexagon around it, indented the surface, cut extruded a star, did some guesswork with the swords, and cut extruded class names on the back and it turned out great!

print_settings.Notes:: I printed in HIPs since that's what I had for blue.

description.text:
I got sick of my soap constantly slipping off the spiky tray in the shower. This soap dish has sides to keep the soap from sliding away, spikes to keep the soap high and dry, and large slots in the bottom to let the water out. Since I designed it for the shower, it just lets the water drain out the bottom. To use it by a sink, you'll need a tray or other drainage route to keep your counter from getting slimed.


Outside dimensions: 95mm x 70 mm x 20 mm
Inside dimensions: 89mm x 64mm x 10mm (from lip to tip of spikes)

It's a pretty close fit for the soap I use, so you may need to scale up slightly if you use larger bars of soap.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Supports:

No

Notes:

I printed in HIPs since that's what I had for blue.
Holder for mega fuses, glue the bolts and use small screws secure the cover

description.text:
A mounting bracket that can hold a flashlight onto a flat post. I designed it to hold my HexBright flashlight onto one of the posts of my bed so it is in easy reach at night.

The unit can fit any circular flashlight up to about 40mm in diameter. There are 2 holes running through the back meant to use zip ties to secure the mount onto the desired location.

Updated taller design for taller flashlights. This design has holes for 3 zip ties for mounting.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm or 0.3mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I printed it in Makergeeks Glow-In-The-Dark PETG at 0.3mm layer height. For PLA I would probably use 0.2mm layer height instead.

print_settings.Notes:: 60mm/s

title: Educational Force Sensor + Lab Exercises
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
3D printers are becoming more prevalent in schools these days, but what kinds of education specific things can they be used for? Why not an introductory lesson in physics?!!

This is a functioning 3D printed load cell model capable of measuring force in tension and compression. You can change out the spring to measure forces up to 20 lbs! Links to the purchased parts and lessons explaining the science behind it are all provided in this Thingiverse post!

This hands-on project is safe for kids and the result is durable and can be used for future educational experiments!

Video Demo Here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wAwtl4TtXP8

Update: Links to the non-printed parts for quick reference here:
Hardware:
(1) Spring (Spring-rate = 5.1 lb/in): http://www.mcmaster.com/#9657K428
(1) Alternate Spring (Rate = 3.77 lb/in): http://www.mcmaster.com/#9657K115
(1) Alternate Spring (Rate = 10 lb/in): http://www.mcmaster.com/#9657K429
(1) Sliding Potentiometer (2.36 inch travel): https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9119
(1) 1/4"-20 nut
(1) 1/4"-20 hex bolt, 4" long, PARTIALLY threaded (not fully threaded)

Data Acquisition:
(1) Arduino Uno (Program in the ThingFiles) http://amzn.to/1XrtSUa
(1) Screen Interface (this is optional because you can just use the Arduino serial monitor on the computer to read measurements. The buttons are overkill for this project but they are nice to have for other things.) http://amzn.to/2b47mQ8

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Printrbot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

15% Minimum

Notes:

Any material will work!

Deburr all printed parts

Just be sure to remove all traces of printing support/raft/scaffold/brim etc because these parts snap fit and slide together.

Measure, Model, Print!

First I designed the basic functioning device with a pencil and paper. Then I purchased all the non-printed hardware I knew I would need. Then I used digital calipers to measure the part dimensions and make 3d models of the fasteners, spring, and potientometer. Then I modeled the printable parts to match my concept drawings. When doing this I always try to minimize overhanging edges and ultrafine features that make 3d printing difficult. After I printed the parts I cleaned them up and test fit everything together. If the sliding connections were too tight or the press fit connections were too lose I would go back and adjust the model and reprint it to test it out again. (Oh yea, I used #CubifyDesign for my 3d models)

3D Printed Force Sensor for the Classroom

This is a partially 3d printed spring based force measuring tool.

Overview & Background:

In this Thingiverse Project I'm going to show you how to build a functioning 3D printed load cell model capable of measuring force in tension & compression. This project will give students a hands-on focus and a segway for more technical scientific discussions.

Objectives:

Using this printed force sensor students can learn:
1.How it Works (Hooke's Law)
2.How this compares to a professional load cell.
3.How do we even define what a pound is? (Calibration)
4.Digital electronic measurements: Bit Resolution & Proportional Scaling.

Audiences:

This tool is intended as tool for use in a science (physics) lesson/class. The intended audience for the full lessons are middle school through high school students, although the finished tool/toy itself can be enjoyed by all ages.

Subjects:

Physics, Math, Science, Computers/electronics

Skills Learned (Standards):

Hooke's Law & how to determine the spring rate of an unknown spring.
Wiring up a potentiometer.
Wiring up & programming Arduino.

Lesson/Activity:

Lessons take the form of guided discussion and experimentation with the device, intended in a specific order. (The complexity increases as you go!)
Please refer to the ThingFiles download section for PDF files. Here are the steps for reference:
Step1_PrintableParts&_BOM
Step2_Assemble_The_Parts
Step3_Wire_It_Up_and_Play!
Step4_Discuss_How_It_Works+Mystery_Spring_Exercise
Step5_Comparison_to_Real_Load_Cell
Step6_Perform_A_Calibration
(See MS Excel based Step6_Calibration_Calculator)
Step7_Discuss_BitResolution&_Proportional_Scaling
(See MS Excel based Step7_Printed_LoadCell_Calculations)
Quiz_Loadcell_Lab

Duration:

Consider each step a 15 minute activity with the difficultly level increasing as you go. Although the explanation and discussion itself can last as long as the kids remain interested enough to ask questions!

Preparation:

It helps a lot to have assembled the parts at least once before you introduce them to the kids. (Just to make sure everything fits!) Then disassemble them before class so the kids can rebuild them to achieve the 'i-made-this' feeling. (If you have a late high school class then yuo can just let them 3d print the parts by themselves.)
It also helps if the teacher is familiar enough with Arduino to be able to assist in uploading the program and perhaps editing a variable or 2.

References

The teachers will definitely want to read through the entire lesson before hand to make sure than they themselves understand what it is that they are sharing!

Rubric & Assessment:

Students should be able to answer all the questions on the quiz handout. They should be able to tell you what would happen if you were to do the following:
Use a stronger or weaker spring
Use a longer or shorter potentiometer
Use a different bit measurement system
Also:
What is Hookes Law
How do we define what a lb actually is
How to determine the spring rate of an unknown spring

Handouts & Assets:

See optional quiz handout. If the students are young then give them this at the beginning of class and have them turn it in after you perform the lab as a class or in small groups.

This generic ball socket design can be customized to snap onto the end of any ball fitting, and provides a flat mounting surface to attach objects using double sided tape, adhesive, etc.

This particular STL included was design to mount a Seek thermal camera to coolant hose so it can be positioned easily. The mounting pad attaches to a USB adapter which is needed to connect the thermal camera to a PC.

You may need to tweak the ballClearance and openingAngle to get the right amount of friction when rotating, and also the amount of force to snap into place or remove.
I printed my part in PETG which does not warp/shrink perceptibly when the part cools, and found that 0.35mm clearance gave a reasonable fit. Other plastics or printers with different tolerances may require more clearance for a good fit.

title: Raspberry Pi Camera Objective Lens Adaptor

description.text:
Holder which mounts microscope objective lens (reversed) on Raspberry Pi Camera v2.1 board. Connects to PCB with 4x M2 screws + nuts. OpenSCAD file can be modified for other objective lenses. This one fits an AmScope 4x objective http://www.ebay.com/itm/381613828736 which acts as a long telephoto on the RPi camera (250 mm equivalent on a full-frame SLR). UPDATE: added optional part; a mounting ring with pocket to capture a 1/4-20 hex nut, to accept a standard camera tripod mount.

The resolution test (ring pattern) above is a 1:1 crop of the 8Mpixel camera image, showing a target measuring 18 cm across the "T" marks at a distance of 9.6 m. I calculate this lens has f=27 mm and HFOV ~ 8 degrees on this sensor.

You do need to remove the factory lens first, so the sensor is uncovered. You can use one of the lens tools to crack open the glue on the lens thread; either http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1557754 or http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1574661

UPDATE: For anyone needing a long lens for the RPi v2 Camera, I now recommend you consider printing this M12 adaptor mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1963856 for use with a M12 lens such as http://www.ebay.com/itm/282167088666 which I have found has good image quality. Perhaps better than the microscope objective used here.

title: Hitachi DCG-306 Carburetor gasket Datsun 120Y (B210) etc.

description.text:
I needed a new float chamber gasket for my Datsun 120Y (B210). The previous one had deteriorated too much and it was hand cut anyway so it had tears and poor holes for various jets etc.
This new gasket was made by scanning the carb on a normal photo scanner and drawing the path in inkscape. then tweaking in the free version of solid edge and finally zapping it with a lasercutter. I'm using a rather thick gasket due to misalignment of the carb body.
The dark muck on the edges is burnt material from the cutting process. I expect that this needs to be cleaned or it will affecct nozzles and jets. Feel free to praise me if this works for you and hope the same technique works for other carbs too. remember to protect your (or your pals) scanner glass with a plastic sheet before you stick the carb on it :D Update:
Gasket is now installed. Works ok.
I have a faulty secondary emulsion tube. It doesn't seat properly. This causes the secondary body to stand proud. This means I had to cut this gasket slightly to accomodate.
The design has been tested on an other carb without this fault and it seats ok.
Also extra reminder to scrape the edge of the gasket to get rid of the burnt material to prevent clogging.
I also fixed the faulty advertising in the name of this thing. Perhaps in the future I'll get to making a printable carb :D

comments.text: Hey, I created a group called Datsun Parts and Needs. If you would like to join and post this there, I would greatly appreciate it!
comments.author: ethan07e

comments.text: This is awesome! It's good to know that the old gaskets can be re-made. What material did you use for the gasket?
comments.author: Blackcloud

comments.text:
Hi!
I used generic gasket material I bought at an auto parts shop. I think this was the thickest sheet they had (slightly over 1mm), though it shouldn't matter what thickness you use as long as it works.
I can say now after a year of use that the gasket has worked fine.
I can't remember the laser cutter power settings we used but it certainly wasn't the full power of it (120W laser).
Hope it works for you!

title: Dominion Justifier Heavy Grav-Tank (15mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Trilobite Pattern Justifier, super heavy grav-tank for the Trans-Universal Dominion forces.

This miniature was designed for Wayfarer Tactics, our fast, modular (as in "fully customizable") miniature gaming rules. If you want to check it out, it's totally free here on our site, so give it a download!. It is, of course, useful for any 15mm scale miniature wargame or RPG. If you want 28mm scale versions, just increase the size by 180% (provided your build plate can handle it).

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

ASSEMBLY

No glue is required for assembling this model. As long as your printer is calibrated, the tolerances are such that the base snaps right in. The roof fits snugly, as does the turret, which can swivel. The face plate is slippery and difficult to keep on if unpainted, though once painted it has enough tack to stick in place (as long as you don't jostle it too much).

remixed_from.title: "Smartrap CoreXY"-like X Carriage with internal clamping belts (gets rid of the "in-the-way" belt clamping ears)")

remixed_from.author: mbthor
remixed_from.title: 3D Printer 3xLM8UU Minimal X Carriage (with symmetric/balanced tensioning mechanism) [#SCOUTcorexy design]

title: 3D Printer 4xLM8UU Minimal X Carriage (with symmetric/balanced tensioning mechanism) for F694zz bearings & more [#SCOUTcorexy design]

description.text:
This is the evolution of the 3xLM8UU Minimal X-Carriage with balanced belt-tensioner (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1505842) that I have previously developed for SCOUTcorexy 3D Printed (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1487375).

It is not replacing it as that one servers the purpose very well but this is an effort to have 4 bearings for those who want them.

I made this one modular so I or anybody else can just replace the belt-grippers at will, printing them alone if the bearings on their Y axis changes for some reason without re-printing the whole X carriage. I have added a way to fix one module to the X Carriage body should you decide to go for the modular approach (expecting to change them at some point and don't want to re-print the carriage), namely a nut in the body of the X-carriage which will restrain the movement of the module opposed to it.

The advantage of increased rigidity due to the internal belt grippers is maintained.

Please ask questions if you have any, I will try to respond to every single one of them.
You might also be interested in the 3D printer I am designing this X Carriage for: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1487375 (View it in 3D @Sketchfab: http://is.gd/1l27lz)

Update 08/07/2016: added the YCarriage that goes with this XCarriage design. Distance between rods 40mm.

comments.text: Clicked though 3 different iterations to make it here. What an adventure!  Great idea, looking forward to printing it.
comments.author: Bwahahahaha

comments.text: Can you add the file for the y linkage? I modified the STL to fit 8mm bearings, but having the source would make it more kosher.
comments.author: chuffine

comments.text: SCOUTcorexy 3D Printer .. This is horizontal.  What are the corresponding Y-Idlers for this X-carriage.
comments.author: g2david

comments.text: attached to this thing the YCarriage that goes with this design. I have discontinued working on the vertical stack for now, concentrating on the Horizontal Printing Head arrangement (see my latest modes) because the vertical stacking has some flaws that can not be easily overcome (nozzle can't be dead centered to minimize effects of acellerations, rod flex, etc) and the weight of the carriage is difficult to balance so it is the same on both sides of the rods.
comments.author: g2david

comments.text: thanks for sharing your experience. Before that, I think vertical stacking is more flexible for me to change my x-carriage. Definitely I will print the ScoutCorexy printer
comments.author: mbthor

comments.text: Please bear in mind that this is all made for a custom reprap 3D printer I am designing and hopefully will build sometime soon and that the distances are all specific to SCOUTcorexy. If you want to print bits and pieces out of context you will not be able to match them to an existing design without some work on adjusting parameters.
comments.author: g2david

comments.text: Beautiful work man. I think your design is so nice looking as well as functional
comments.author: dangerousf00d

comments.text: Thank you. Vertical XCarriage would work well unless you want high speeds, in which case they are not the best for the job. I started with Vertical XCarriage because it's simpler to design, uses less plastic, is easier overall. But from a stricter engineering pov the horizontal XCarriage, when done properly, can outperform the vertical arrangement.

title: LCD and switch holder for a BigBox printer

description.text:
This is a special ad-don for a BigBox (Dual or Pro) printer. Since the case-fan always runs on 100% and makes a lot of noise, I decided to control the fan with an Arduino via PWM. The setup is simple: I measure the in-going and out-going air temperature. If the difference exceeds a certain level, I increase the speed of the case-fan via a PID regulator.

The print holds a standard LCD (I2C) screen (1602) and two buttons with a hole size of 15mm.

See also this thread on the BigBox forum:
http://forum.e3d-online.com/index.php?threads/project-whisper-arduino-version.1135/
